posts.name: Michael
posts.cooked:
Hey everyone,

We are attempting to constantly reset the robot position on a coordinate system based on AprilTag updates with during our auto path to protect against any drift. Do any of you have ideas on how to make it smoother as currently the discrepancies in estimated positions are making the robot constantly jerk around? Should I only rely on AprilTags to reset our odometry at the beginning of our autonomous period?

Any help is greatly appreciated!

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked: Things that might be interesting to research/experiment with: Pose Estimators Occasional updates instead of consistent Signal Filtering

posts.custom_user_title: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.name: Michael Ray
posts.cooked:
Only set the X and Y of your swerve odometry from your limelight pose.

Try and ignore rotation in the pose - let the rotation only come from your pigeon or NavX

posts.name: Michael
posts.cooked: I’ve tried occasional updates but since position seems to get more and more inaccurate it jerks further on every update.

posts.name: Michael Jansen
posts.cooked:
By “reset position” do you actually mean you’re resetting the position or are you using the addVisionMeasurement method? If you’re not using that method you’ll definitely want to do that over hard resetting odometry.

I would also recommend against correcting odom while path following. It will be able to remain pretty accurate while following the path. If you’re going to correct in auto you should do it while not moving.
For anyone reading, this won’t really help with the tag jitter / ambiguity (common misconception) , but is still reccomended.

posts.name: Michael
posts.cooked:
Yes, we are using the addVisionMeasurement method.

We tried setting the reading from the limelight at the beginning of our path and it works. Thank you so much!

Has anyone played with adjusting the pose estimator measurement covariances depending on the pose?  I’m hearing that head on with the tag seems to be the worst place since the estimate is very sensitive to pixel quantization / noise.
